text:
Got it. So Toddle is a pro code tool that supercharges how devs work and helps them grow skill-wise.
I was skimming your site, hence, probably didn’t grasp what your website was trying to communicate. Also, I’m probably biased by the AI hype :sweat_smile:.

The AI believers would say that no-code tools, like lovable (which is just amazing btw!) will improve - there will be better ways to “interact” with them. They will become explainable and human-workflow compatible.
If that is the case, then these AI models will be as good as a software developer, and can effectively replace (the entire or part of) the development team, and still be useful for production (and no longer be just “for fun”). That sounds like a real threat to tools like Toddle and traditional SWE, if - and big if - it happens.

Anyway, Lovable’s ARR is off the roof. Any guesses, if it’s from users just trying out the product, or from users deploying them to production?
PS: You can probably try to figure out if any of them are disgruntled and win them over to your side :upside_down_face:

text:
Our target audience is developers and product designers so there is not much overlap with lovables customer base.

The hype around AI is understandable. The AI agents are really fun to play with, but their actual use cases are very limited. You can’t build a viable product in lovable and that is very unlikely to change any time soon

but their actual use cases are very limited. You
build a viable product in lovable and that is very unlikely to change any time soon

text:
That is not to say AI is not useful in programming, tools like cursor can help automate a lot of tedious tasks in programming.

The idea that we don’t need programmers any more is rubbish though. And AI also does not make programming easier in any significant sense

text:
What's up everyone! So happy to have finally joined! I'm George, I am currently working on developing my coding/engineering skills full-time after being employed as a barista for the past year. I studied computer science for several years in Boston, but was deeply unsatisfied with both the general CS curriculum and my own academic performance, so I dropped out to pursue other things. I grew up in Tyngsborough, a tiny town outside Boston, and now live in southern Maine. I've always been a fan of this community and it had a huge influence on my decision to go back to school this coming summer, where I will be studying sociology. I don't think I know anyone from here personally, but Maya Avendaño and of course Maggie Appleton have inspired me for quite a while now.

My first project is a lofi web radio for Byzantine music of the Eastern Orthodox Church, which will be released soon. I'm very excited to meet and learn with others in this community!

I studied computer science for several years in Boston, but was deeply unsatisfied with both the general CS curriculum and my own academic performance, so I dropped out to pursue other things. I grew up in Tyngsborough, a tiny town outside Boston, and now live in southern Maine. I've always been a fan of this community and it had a huge influence on my decision to go back to school this coming summer, where I will be studying sociology. I don't think I know anyone from here personally, but Maya Avendaño and of course Maggie Appleton have inspired me for quite a while now.

My first project is a lofi web radio for Byzantine music of the Eastern Orthodox Church, which will be released soon. I'm very excited to meet and learn with others in this community!

text:
Hello everyone! I'm James (<https://jamesg.blog>) :sparkles: I have been lurking for a little while and wanted to say hello!

I am thinking more about tools that encourage me to create with my phone. Last year, I made a <https://github.com/capjamesg/knowledge-graph-language|query language for knowledge graphs> that I plan to continue working on soon. I am also thinking about a minimal interface for authoring HTML documents on mobile devices (how concise can the syntax be?).

I also maintain a website that lists <https://airportpianos.org|what airports have pianos>.

It's great to be here!

text:
Hi there!

I'm Sidney Congard, I worked 3 years as a C++ programmer then went back to studies: I'm now a phd student in programming languages (in France), flavored with linear logic. I'm interested in the treatment of mutability in programming (e.g. borrows), and more generally by the merry mess that is coding.

I came to lurk and perhaps exchange on similar topics :)
